qas.question: What reflector can change the waves polarization?
What will you be matching with the  receiving antenna's polarization?
What stays the same regarding polarization state at the recieving location?
What is the name used for signals recieved following reflection by the ionosphere?

context: <a0_0>Reflections<a0_0/> generally affect polarization. For radio waves, one important reflector is the <a1_0>ionosphere<a1_0/> which can change the wave's polarization. Thus for signals received following reflection by the ionosphere (<a4_0>a skywave<a4_0/>), a consistent polarization cannot be expected. For line-of-sight communications or ground wave propagation, horizontally or vertically <a3_0>polarized transmissions<a3_0/> generally remain in about the same polarization state at the receiving location. Matching the receiving antenna's polarization to that of the <a2_0>transmitter<a2_0/> can make a very substantial difference in received signal strength.
